headline: World's Best Potato Soup
description: Potatoes, onions, and celery cooked in chicken broth are combined with half-and-half, crisp bacon, and condensed cream of mushroom soup in this chowder with cheddar cheese.

video.description: A delicious, chunky and creamy potato soup with bacon.
video.name: World's Best Potato Soup

name: World's Best Potato Soup
recipeIngredient: 1 (10.75 ounce) can condensed cream of mushroom soup

recipeInstructions.text: In a large stock pot combine potatoes, onions, celery, bouillon cubes and enough water to cover all ingredients. Bring to a boil and simmer on medium heat until potatoes are with in 15 minutes of being finished.
Add half and half, bacon, cream of mushroom soup and stir until creamy. Add cheese and stir until completely melted. Simmer on low until potatoes are done.

review.reviewBody: This turned out to be a great soup, but the way it’s written is subject to interpretation, and there are unknown factors. “8 potatoes” can vary greatly in size, as well as “enough water to cover all ingredients.” So, I measured most everything I did, and it ended up to be 5 stars. I also took the advice of some reviews, such as cutting down chicken broth because of saltiness, using less bacon, and adding carrots. I peeled the potatoes because my husband can’t eat potato skins. I used 12 small and medium ones and it was easily 4-1/2 cups. I used 1 diced celery stalk, a medium chopped onion, and 1/2 to 3/4 cup of minced carrots and sautéed them in some butter for a few minutes, then added 3 cups of water to cover and 3 teaspoons of chicken broth powder. Also sprinkled a little garlic powder in it. Cubed potatoes do not need to cook initially for 15 minutes, so I cooked it (covered) a lot less than the recipe states. (One reviewer suggested removing 1/3 of the water after cooking and before adding anything else, but I did not do that.) Then I added the mushroom soup and 3/4 of a 12 oz. package of good turkey bacon. I realized that if I added an entire pint of half & half, it would be too thin for our liking, so I added only a 1/2 cup, and then only 3/4 cup of medium cheddar cheese. It turned out great, and the next day it was even better! It had thickened more by then, so I added a little more half and half when I reheated it. I’ll be making this again!

This is a terrible recipe. It wasn't at all thick. Why leave the skins on? They just come off and float around. Didn't have much flavor but I followed what a commentor said and added things so it did. The cheese did not incorporate at all. I did a roux to thicken the soup and if I had added milk and cheese to that and then added that to the soup it might have worked out. It would be good to specify the type and size of potatoes as well. Also, adding bacon into the pot is a bad idea because it will get soft. But it makes sense as a topping. There are definitely better potato soup recipes.

I boiled the potatoes then rough mashed about half of them putting them back into a cup of the potato liquid (for the starch) added 2 cups of chicken broth (use more broth or water if it's needed to cover everything) and put the veggies in with the potato mixture let simmer, add a pint of half and half (or heavy cream), a regular can of cream of mushroom soup - salt and pepper to taste at this point - let it get slow bubbly hot again and slowly add as much milk as you like - less for thicker soup more for thinner soup - when it is nice and bubbly add cheese ( I used Colby, Swiss and sharp cheddar combined) when the cheese is melted stir in 8 ozs of sour cream and bacon - garnish as desired. It is heavenly.
